column158:
What works well in our current partner engagement strategy is a mix of structured communication, tangible value delivery, and clear reporting.

We activate each partnership with tailored promotions and keep benefits “always on” through the partner’s internal or external channels. This helps ensure visibility and continuous traffic.

We also provide monthly reports with key metrics such as usage of the benefit, traffic driven, sales generated, and the top courses purchased. This data-driven approach helps us keep partners engaged, prove ROI, and identify new opportunities together.

Finally, we strengthen trust and retention by collaborating on co-branded initiatives like workshops, certifications, or joint campaigns. This allows partners not only to promote learning but also to showcase their brand as part of our students’ education journey.
column159:
One area that still needs improvement is partner communication and activation in markets where our brand is less recognized. While we provide ongoing benefits and campaigns, partners sometimes deprioritize communication as they manage multiple offerings for their audiences.

Another area is ensuring consistent tracking and reporting. Not all partners use our tracking links or tools, which limits visibility into true performance. We’re working on building stronger processes and incentives to improve adoption.
column160:
Over the past two years, our strategy has shifted from purely discount-driven partnerships to a model that emphasizes co-branding, certification, and community engagement.

We realized that driving revenue through partnerships requires more than just offering benefits. By having companies certify our courses, co-host workshops, or integrate into our platform, we create tangible value and trust for students while giving partners deeper brand visibility and talent pipelines.

This evolution was driven by the need to increase brand awareness in competitive markets and to ensure partnerships contribute not only to sales but also to long-term positioning.
column161:
AI will fundamentally change the way we design partnerships. With our upcoming AI-powered platform, we can personalize learning paths in real time, ensuring that partner content, tools, or certifications are always up to date and relevant.

This means partners can integrate more seamlessly into the student journey, with content refreshed in hours instead of months. AI also allows us to identify patterns in student demand and propose collaborations with partners that directly match market needs.

Ultimately, AI enables partnerships to move from transactional to dynamic and adaptive relationships, where value for students and partners is continuously optimized.
column162:
We see partnerships as one of the most powerful drivers of growth for EdTech. At Coderhouse, partnerships already account for a significant share of new students and revenue, but more importantly, they allow us to bridge companies, talent, and education in a scalable way.

We’d love to see more industry benchmarks and case studies around partnerships not just as sales channels, but as strategic levers for trust, talent development, and brand building.

column160:
Partnership was almost non existent when I was moved from an AE role to a Partner Manager role.

First of the platform was changed from First Promoter to Parter.io.
In 6 months I grew the program to 150+ new partners. And generated $300k in new revenue sourced from partners. Fun fact: Closed won pipeline for H1 2025 was bigger than Closed Lost pipeline for the same period sourced by partners.

This month I got the first new team member, and we got some miss-aligned goals with management, so numbers are 0's across the board.
column161:
Faster success proof. 
Easier management.

column158: Driving towards partner first party outcomes we unlock (their own professional services, closer relationship/tie ins with MSFT, solving customer pain points) is where we by far exceed our metrics. In both channel (resale/services) and with MSFT (resale/services/product) our solution is relevant and in demand - so that does help gloss over some difficulties we have (internal resourcing, operational immaturity).
column159: We are actually so Marketplace-forward that the traditional channel partners i.e. CDW have not yet caught up to our motion. We have to still build a traditional disti/resale model to get people to pay attention since we're ahead of the market in MP.
column160: Move up market to national solution providers/SIs from regional/niche workload players. All about market and customer reach as well as getting away from one-trick partners and those still clinging to our legacy competition.
column161: Not sure I can touch this one credibly - we're still looking for the operational efficiency gains before looking beyond. Gong, the LLMs, etc have certainly taken steps in that direction. In partnerships I feel like there's a need for "alignment" on how to use AI together, and that becomes a cultural/technological exchange we'd have to work through inside of each partnership.

column158:
Our structured onboarding and enablement programs give partners a clear path to get trained and certified quickly.

Co-sell alignment through account mapping and opportunity sharing helps drive sourced and influenced revenue.

Partner events and town halls create strong engagement and visibility.

Tools like the PRM, playbooks, and co-marketing resources make it easier for partners to access what they need.

Executive and field involvement keeps top partners aligned and supported.
column159:
We need to scale faster — current resourcing creates bottlenecks in onboarding, enablement, and co-sell support.

Processes are still too manual; more automation is needed across PRM, reporting, and license workflows.

Communication and visibility for mid-tier partners could be stronger, so they feel supported without heavy 1:1 time.

Our partner portal is improving but still lacks the seamless experience and depth of resources partners expect.

Better alignment is needed between marketing, sales, and product teams to deliver a more consistent partner experience.
column160:
We formalized our partner program with clear tiers, onboarding journeys, and certification requirements.

We invested in technology like PRM, Crossbeam, and enablement platforms to automate processes and provide more visibility.

Our focus expanded from just channel resale to a broader mix of solution partners, ISVs, and marketplace relationships.

Engagement moved from one-off activities to consistent programs — roadshows, partner town halls, co-marketing, and advisory boards.

What drove these changes:

Executive alignment on partnerships as a core revenue lever.

The need to scale globally while improving partner experience.

Demand from partners for more enablement, co-sell support, and predictable processes.

Market growth opportunities that require ecosystem collaboration rather than direct selling alone.
column161:
It can personalize enablement and recommendations for each partner, tailoring content, training, and plays to their maturity and focus.

AI can give partners real-time insights into market trends, customer needs, and integration opportunities, making them more consultative and valuable to customers.

It could reshape co-selling by analyzing data across ecosystems to surface the best joint opportunities and predict win likelihood.

AI-driven support tools can help partners troubleshoot faster, deliver higher-quality implementations, and increase customer satisfaction.

Longer term, AI may open new business models where partners package Celigo solutions with their own IP or industry expertise in smarter, more scalable ways.
column162: Partnerships are core to our growth strategy, and we’ve made significant progress in building a more structured, scalable, and partner-friendly program. Our biggest focus now is balancing growth with resources, continuing to automate processes, expand enablement, and improve partner experience while driving measurable revenue impact. Continued investment in partner operations and technology will be key to sustaining momentum.

column158: CAM team field engagement with partners is working well. Meeting face to face with partners and enabling them is driving new pipeline. Joint field events are yielding new opportunities and improved partner relationships.
column159: Self service enablement needs attention, but lack of resources are slowing us down to update trainings. Not having a dedicated partner marketing person currently means missed opportunities that could improve partner engagement and drive new pipeline. Not having a dedicated operations person means we are not being as efficient as we could be if we had better data driven visibility in to the business to build from. Field engagement with the MP partners could improve to unlock additional forms of budget and opportunity acceleration.
column160: Our strategy has evolved with the inclusion of integration Tech partners as a new route to market to draft off of the larger SIEM industry names. This was driven by our new technology innovations. We also unified the two partner teams in to one team to drive the ecosystem synergies that will help all partnerships grow.
column161: We are still learning and experimenting with how AI will help our partner ecosystem. Some partners have adopted our solutions with their own AI services to create unique offerings to jointly take to market. These programs are in early stages right now, so the ROI effectiveness can't be measured yet.
column162: The Channel ecosystem revenues continue to grow and all vendors want to be part of the growth. To be part of the growth, leadership needs to invest in the resources just like they do in direct sales and marketing. Hopefully this survey can help bring that gap.
